front.title: Use of BGP for Opaque Signaling

abstract.t: Border Gateway Protocol with multi-protocol extensions (MP-BGP) enables the use of the protocol for dissemination of virtually any information. This document proposes a new Address Family/Subsequent Address Family to be used for distribution of opaque data. This functionality is intended to be used by applications other than BGP for exchange of their own data on top of BGP mesh. The structure of such data SHOULD NOT be interpreted by the regular BGP speakers, rather the goal is to use BGP purely as a convenient and scalable communication system.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Implementation of Multiprotocol Extensions for BGP-4 gives the ability to pass arbitrary data in BGP protocol messages. This capability has been leveraged by many for dissemination of non-routing related information over BGP (e.g. "Dissemination of Flow Specification Rules" as well as "North-Bound Distribution of Link-State and TE Information using BGP"). However, there has been no channel defined explicitly to disseminate data with arbitrary payload. The intended use case is for applications other than BGP to leverage the protocol machinery for distribution (broadcasting) of their own state in the network domain. Publishers and consumers will use BGP UPDATE messages to submit and receive opaque data. It is up to the BGP implementation to provide a custom API for message producers or consumers if needed.
One application of this extension could be auto-discovery of various services in the data-center network that uses BGP as the routing protocol of choice ().

Another application is building and testing new routing protocols or BGP extensions within existing BGP implementation. The new protocol/extension may influence routing either by directly communicating to the RIB/FIB of the router it runs on, or by overriding BGP paths via BGP route injection. section.title: BGP Opaque Data AFI
section.t: This document introduces a new AFI known as a "BGP Opaque Data AFI" with the actual value to be assigned by IANA. The purpose of this AFI is to exchange opaque information within a BGP network.

section.title: BGP Key-Value SAFI
section.t: This document introduces a new SAFI known as "BGP Key-Value SAFI" with the actual value to be assigned by IANA. The purpose of this SAFI is exchange of opaque information structured as a Key-Value binding.

section.title: BGP Key-Value VPN SAFI
section.t: This document introduces a new SAFI known as a "BGP Key-Value VPN SAFI" with the actual value to be assigned by IANA. The purpose of this SAFI is exchange of opaque information structured as a Key-Value binding over service provider backbone providing Virtual Private Networks as a service.

defines a method and procedures for implementing VPNs using BGP as a control plane. All the procedures of applies to the BGP Key-Value VPN SAFI. To facilitate the support for VPNs, the NLRI for the opaque information has 8 bytes of Route Distinguisher at the beginning of the NLRI field.

section.title: Capability Advertisement
section.t: A BGP speaker that wishes to exchange Opaque Data MUST use the Multiprotocol Extensions Capability Code, as defined in , to advertise the corresponding AFI/SAFI pair.

section.title: Disseminating Key-Value bindings
section.t:
This document proposes to implement a distributed, eventually consistent Key-Value store on top of existing BGP protocol mechanics. The "Key" portion is to be encoded as the NLRI part of MP_REACH_NLRI attribute and "Value" encoded using a new optional transitive attribute.
Publishers, acting as BGP speakers, advertise keys along with associated values into the routing domain. The BGP network synchronizes that state by propagating the encoded data following regular BGP protocol operations.
Consumers, acting as BGP speakers, receive the information via BGP protocol UPDATE messages. Only publishers and consumers of the opaque data are supposed to interpret its contents - the rest of the BGP network acts merely as a dissemination system.

Multiple publishers can advertise the same key (NLRI) bound to different values. It is also possible for the advertised binding to have the same Key-Value pairs but differ in some other BGP attributes. In that case, BGP would follow the best-path selection logic to prevent duplicate information in the network. A consumer will receive the value created by the publisher "closest" in terms of BGP best-path selection logic, based on the policies that exist in the routing domain. This document does not propose any method of achieving global consensus for all published values for a given key.

section.title: Publishing a Key-Value binding
section.t: The encoding scheme proposed below follows the semantics of a Key-Value bindings. The "Key" is stored in the NLRI section of the MP_REACH_NLRI attribute, as shown on .

list.t: The AFI/SAFI values are to be allocated by IANA.
Length of Next Hop Address: must be zero.

Opaque Key Length: identifies the size of the Key field in octets. If field is set to zero, the implementation MUST ignore the advertisement. The Key length of 2 octets allows BGP Opaque SAFI to carry NLRI longer than 255 octets. This document defines a maximum Key Length of 4000 bytes. Message where the Key value length exceeds 4000 MUST be ignored, and this event MAY be logged.

Opaque Key Data: the byte string representing the opaque key contents. For Key-Value VPN SAFI, the key data field starts with 8 bytes of Route Distinguisher corresponding to the originator of the key value.

section.t: The "Value" portion of a published binding is to be encoded in a new optional non-transitive attribute as shown on :

list.t: Attr Flags reflect that the attribute is optional and non-transitive. The implementations MUST set the extended length bit to "1", thus requiring the attribute length field of two octets.
Attr Type Code: Identifies the new OPAQUE_VALUE attribute, with the value to be allocated by IANA.
Attr Length: the full length of the attribute, two octets.

AS Number: Four octets encoding the AS Number of an Autonomous System originating the key-value binding. If set to non-zero, the receiving BGP speaker SHOULD validate this field for correctness, e.g. making sure it does not carry reserved AS number values. In case of format violation, the receiving speaker SHOULD ignore the attribute and MAY log this event.

Originator ID: 16 Octets encoding the Originator ID value. If set to non-zero, the Originator ID SHOULD be interpreted an IPv6 address of a node originating the NLRI. In case if the sending node does not have an IPv6 addresses, the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address SHOULD be used. If set to non-zero, the receiving BGP speaker SHOULD validate the field to be a syntactically valid IPv6 or IPv4 unicast address. In case of format violation, the receiving speaker SHOULD ignore the attribute value and MAY log this event.

Opaque Value Length: Two octets encoding the total length of the attribute in octets, including the Type and Length fields. The length is encoded as an unsigned binary integer. The four most significant bits of this field MUST be set to zero, due to the limit imposed by maximum BGP message size. Note that the minimum length is "3", indicating that no Opaque Value Data field is present. Such binding, in presence of non-zero length key is still valid, as it informs the consumers that the key "exists".
Opaque Value Data: A field containing zero or more octets. This portion SHOULD NOT be interpreted by BGP implementations.

section.t: The AS Number and the Originator ID COULD be used to ensure key uniqueness among multiple autonomous systems. If not needed, those field SHOULD be set to zero and ignored by the implementation.

Even when the OPAQUE_VALUE attribute is not present in BGP advertisement, the BGP implementation MUST still retain Opaque Key (NLRI) in its LocRIB and propagate it further as usual. This case is to be interpreted as an announcement of the key existence.

The maximum size of the opaque Key and Value opaque strings is limited by the BGP UPDATE message size. With the default protocol implementation is may not exceed 4KB, however if is implemented it could be as large as 64KB.

section.title: Removing a Key-Value binding
section.t: The removal procedure follows the regular MP-BGP route withdrawal, using the MP_UNREACH_NLRI attribute. This section defines the attribute structure for the new AFI/SAFI.

The message shown on instructs the receiving BGP speaker to delete the N bindings corresponding to Key 1, Key 2 ... Key N if the keys have been previously learned from the withdrawing speaker. If any of the Keys is not found in the LocRIB or has not been previously received from the withdrawing BGP peer, such key removal request MUST be ignored.

section.title: Propagating multiple values for the same key
section.t: It is possible to propagate multiple values associated with the same key using the Add-Path extension defined in . However, this document that instead unique key values SHOULD be used for this purpose. It is up to the consumers and publishers of the opaque data to settle on single unique value using some kind of consensus protocol.

section.title: Message filtering
section.t: Limiting the scope of opaque information flooding is an important operational concern. BGP already has the mechanisms needed to control this process, and these mechanisms are briefly reviewed below.

section.title: Automated filtering
section.t: One can leverage mechanics presented in and use the route-target extended community attribute to identify "channels" where key-value bindings are published. The consumers would signal their interest in particular "channel" by advertising the corresponding router-target membership. The publications then need to contain the router-target extended community attribute to constrain information propagation.

section.title: Filtering via policy
section.t: Ad-doc message filtering could be implemented using BGP standard (see ) or extended community attributes (see ). The semantic of these attributes is to determined by the policy and publishers/consumers. Filtering could be done locally on receiving speaker, or on remote speaker, by using outbound route filtering feature defined in .

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: For the purpose of this work, IANA would be asked to allocate values for the new AFI and SAFI, as well as a value for the new optional transitive attribute.
